sen.j: 三十三間堂（さんじゅうさんげんどう）は京都市東山区にある仏堂。
sen.e: Sanjusangen-do Temple is a Buddhist temple located in the Higashiyama Ward of Kyoto City.
Sanjusangen-do Temple is a Buddhist temple located in the Higashiyama Ward of Kyoto City.
Sanjusangen-do Temple is a Buddhist temple located in the Higashiyama Ward of Kyoto City.

sen.j: 建物の正式名称は蓮華王院本堂（れんげおういんほんどう）。
sen.e: It is officially known as Rengeo-in Temple.
It is officially known as Rengeo-in Hondo (the main hall of Rengeo-in Temple).
sen.cmt: Rengeo-in Temple→Rengeo-in Hondo (the main hall of Rengeo-in Temple)
sen.e: It is officially known as Rengeo-in Hondo (the main hall of Rengeo-in Temple).

sen.j: 同じ京都市東山区にある天台宗妙法院の境外仏堂であり、同院が所有・管理している。
sen.e: The site is an external sub-temple of the Myoho-in Tendai sect Temple, also in Kyoto's Higashiyama Ward, by which it is owned and administrated.
sen.cmt: ・Tendai sect: 英辞郎 on the WEB、およびhttp://21dzk.l.u-tokyo.ac.jp/INBUDS/search.php?m=trdd&usid=59058&a=
sen.e: The site is an external sub-temple of the Myoho-in Tendai sect Temple, also in Kyoto's Higashiyama Ward, by which it is owned and administrated.
The site is an external sub-temple of the Myoho-in Tendai sect Temple, also in Kyoto's Higashiyama Ward, by which it is owned and administrated.

sen.j: 元は後白河上皇が自身の離宮内に創建した仏堂で、本尊は千手観音である。
sen.e: It was originally a Buddhist temple built by Emperor Go-Shirakawa within his villa and the principal object of veneration is Senju-Kannon.
sen.cmt: ・Senju Kannon: http://www.kcn-net.org/e_kama_history/glossary/glossary.htm、英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: It was originally a Buddhist temple built by Emperor Go-Shirakawa within his villa and the principal object of veneration is Senju-Kannon.
It was originally a Buddhist temple built by the Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa within his villa and the principal object of veneration is Senju-Kannon.
sen.cmt: Emperor→ex-Emperor"ex-Emperor"→"the Retired Emperor"に変更しました。

sen.j: この地には、もともと後白河上皇が離宮として建てた法住寺殿があった。
sen.e: The site was originally where retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa constructed Hojujidono Temple to serve as his villa.
sen.cmt: ・retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa: プログレッシブ和英中辞典
sen.e: The site was originally where retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa constructed Hojujidono Temple to serve as his villa.
The site was originally where retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa constructed Hojuji-dono Temple to serve as his villa.

sen.j: その広大な法住寺殿の一画に建てられたのが蓮華王院本堂、今に言う三十三間堂である。
sen.e: Rengeo-in Hondo (the main hall of Rengeo-in Temple) was built within the extensive precinct of Hojujidono Temple and this now goes by the name 'Sanjusangen-do Temple'.
Rengeo-in Hondo (the main hall of Rengeo-in Temple) was built within the extensive precinct of Hojujidono Temple and this now goes by the name 'Sanjusangen-do Temple.'
Rengeo-in Hondo (the main hall of Rengeo-in Temple) was built within the extensive precinct of Hojuji-dono Temple and this now goes by the name 'Sanjusangen-do Temple.'

sen.j: 上皇が平清盛に建立の資材協力を命じて旧暦の長寛2年12月17日（西暦1165年1月30日）に完成したという。
sen.e: TAIRA no Kiyomori completed the temple under the order of Emperor Go-Shirakawa on Januarty 30th, 1164.
TAIRA no Kiyomori completed the temple under the order of Emperor Go-Shirakawa on January 30th, 1165.
TAIRA no Kiyomori completed the temple under the order of the Retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa on January 30, 1165.
sen.cmt: Emperor→ex-Emperor日付表記を修正"ex-Emperor"→"the Retired Emperor"に変更しました。

sen.j: 創建当時は五重塔なども建つ本格的な寺院であったが、建長元年（1249年）の火災で焼失した。
sen.e: At the time of its construction, it was a full-scale temple complex with numerous structures including a five-story pagoda, but it suffered a fire in 1249.
sen.cmt: ・five-story pagoda: プログレッシブ和英中辞典
sen.e: At the time of its construction, it was a full-scale temple complex with numerous structures including a five-story pagoda, but it suffered a fire in 1249.
At the time of its construction, it was a full-scale temple complex with numerous structures including a five-story pagoda, but it suffered a fire in 1249.

sen.j: 文永3年（1266年）に本堂のみが再建されている。
sen.e: Only the main hall was rebuilt in 1266.
sen.cmt: ・main hall: 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Only the main hall was rebuilt in 1266.
Only the main hall was rebuilt in 1266.

sen.j: 現在「三十三間堂」と称される堂がそれであり、当時は朱塗りの外装で、内装も極彩色で飾られていたという。
sen.e: This hall is now named 'Sanjusangen-do Temple' and, when rebuilt, the exterior was adorned with vermillion lacquer and the interior was decorated with rich colors.
This hall is now named 'Sanjusangen-do Temple' and, when rebuilt, the exterior was adorned with vermillion lacquer and the interior was decorated with rich colors.
This hall is now named 'Sanjusangen-do Temple' and, when rebuilt, the exterior was adorned with vermillion lacquer and the interior was decorated with rich colors.

sen.j: 建築様式は和様に属する。
sen.e: The building is of a traditional Japanese architectural style.
The building is of a traditional Japanese architectural style.
The building is of a traditional Japanese architectural style.

sen.j: 「三十三間堂」の名称は、間面記法による表記「三十三間四面」（構造）に由来する。
sen.e: The name 'Sanjusangen-do Temple' means '33 ken Temple' and derives from the fact that the structure has a layout of '33 ken, 4 men' (33 ken (lengthwise bays), surrounded by aisles on 4 sides).
The name 'Sanjusangen-do Temple' means '33 ken Temple' and derives from the fact that the structure has a layout of '33 ken, 4 men' (33 ken (lengthwise bays), surrounded by eaves on 4 sides).
The name 'Sanjusangen-do Temple' means '33 ken Temple' and derives from the fact that the structure has a layout of '33 ken, 4 men' (33 ken (lengthwise bays), surrounded by eaves on 4 sides).

sen.j: 「33」は観音に縁のある数字で、『法華経』等に観音菩薩が33種の姿に変じて衆生を救うと説かれることによる。
sen.e: The number '33' has a connection to the deity Kannon and Buddhist texts such as the Lotus Sutra describe how she can present herself in 33 different forms in order to save the sentient beings of the world.

The number '33' has a connection to the deity Kannon and Buddhist texts such as the Lotus Sutra describe how she can present herself in 33 different forms in order to save the sentient beings of the world.

The number '33' has a connection to the deity Kannon and Buddhist texts such as the Lotus Sutra describe how she can present herself in 33 different forms in order to save the sentient beings of the world.

sen.j: 江戸時代には各藩の弓術家により本堂西軒下（長さ約121m）で矢を射る「通し矢」の舞台となった。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the archers of various clans established an archery tournament known as Toshiya along the southern side of the main hall (approximately 121m).
In the Edo period, the archers of various clans established an archery tournament known as Toshiya along the western side of the main hall (approximately 121m).
In the Edo period, the archers of various clans established an archery tournament known as Toshiya along the western side of the main hall (approximately 121m).

sen.j: その伝統に因み、現在は「楊枝のお加持」大法要と同日（1月中旬）に、本堂西側の射程60mの特設射場で矢を射る「三十三間堂大的全国大会」が行われる。
sen.e: Continuing this tradition is the "Sanjusangen-do O-mato Zenkoku Taikai" (national archery competition at Sanjusangen-do Temple) held at the 60m archery range on the southern side of the main building on the same day as same day as the "Yanagi-no-Okaji" Buddhist ritual (mid January).
sen.cmt: ・"Sanjusangen-do O-mato Zenkoku Taikai" (national archery competition at Sanjusangen-do Temple): http://www.kyoto-np.co.jp/kp/topics/eng/2008jan/01-13.html
sen.e: Continuing this tradition is the 'Sanjusangen-do O-mato Zenkoku Taikai' (national archery competition at Sanjusangen-do Temple) held at the 60m archery range on the western side of the main building on the same day as the 'Yanagi-no-Okaji' Buddhist ritual (mid January).
sen.cmt: southern→western「」→ ''on the same day as same day→on the same day
sen.e: Continuing this tradition is the 'Sanjusangen-do O-mato Zenkoku Taikai' (national archery competition at Sanjusangen-do Temple) held at the 60 m archery range on the western side of the main building on the same day as the 'Yanagi-no-Okaji' Buddhist ritual (mid January).
sen.cmt: 単位の前にスペース挿入

sen.j: 弓道をたしなむ女性成年参加者が振袖袴姿で行射する場面は、しばしばニュース番組等で取り上げられる。
sen.e: The sight of adult female participants in full furisode kimono performing archery frequently makes its way onto the television news.
The sight of adult female participants in full furisode kimono performing archery frequently makes its way onto the television news.
The sight of adult female participants in full furisode kimono performing archery frequently makes its way onto the television news.

sen.j: 一般的には「通し矢」と呼ばれているが、60mは弓道競技の「遠的」の射程であり、かつての通し矢とは似て非なるものである。
sen.e: The event is generally referred to as 'Toshiya', but the 60m long range of today's archery competition is somewhat different to the original Toshiya.
The event is generally referred to as 'Toshiya,' but the 60m long range of today's archery competition is somewhat different to the original Toshiya.
sen.cmt: コンマを'' 内に移動。today’s→today's
sen.e: The event is generally referred to as 'Toshiya,' but the 60 m long range of today's archery competition is somewhat different to the original Toshiya.
sen.cmt: 単位の前にスペース挿入

sen.j: 三十三間堂について次のような伝承がある。
sen.e: The following legend is associated with Sanjusangen-do Temple.
The following legend is associated with Sanjusangen-do Temple.
The following legend is associated with Sanjusangen-do Temple.

sen.j: 後白河上皇は長年頭痛に悩まされていた。
sen.e: The retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa suffered from headaches for many years.
sen.cmt: ・retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa: プログレッシブ和英中辞典
sen.e: The retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa suffered from headaches for many years.
The retired Emperor Go-Shirakawa suffered from headaches for many years.

sen.j: 熊野三山参詣の折にその旨を祈願すると、熊野権現から「平等寺 (京都市下京区)の薬師如来に祈れ」とお告げがあった。
sen.e: When he made a pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan and prayed, Kumano Gongen commanded him to "pray to the Yakushi Nyorai of Byodo-ji Temple (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City)".
When he made a pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan and prayed, Kumano Gongen commanded him to 'pray to the Yakushi Nyorai of Byodo-ji Temple (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City).'
When he made a pilgrimage to Kumano Sanzan and prayed, Kumano Gongen commanded him to 'pray to the Yakushi Nyorai of Byodo-ji Temple (Shimogyo Ward, Kyoto City).'

sen.j: そこで因幡堂に参詣すると、上皇の夢に僧が現れ「上皇の前世は熊野の蓮花坊という僧侶で、仏道修行の功徳によって天皇に生まれ変わった。
sen.e: When he visited Inaba-do, a monk appeared to him in a dream and told him "In your previous life, you were a monk from Kunmano named Rengebo who was reincarnated as an emperor in reward for his good deeds.

When he visited Inaba-do, a monk appeared to him in a dream and told him 'In your previous life, you were a monk from Kumano named Rengebo who was reincarnated as an emperor in reward for his good deeds.

When he visited Inaba-do, a monk appeared to him in a dream and told him 'In your previous life, you were a monk from Kumano named Rengebo who was reincarnated as an emperor in reward for his good deeds.

sen.j: しかし、その蓮華坊の髑髏が岩田川の底に沈んでいて、その目穴から柳が生え、風が吹くと髑髏が動くので上皇の頭が痛むのである」と告げた。
sen.e: However, Rengebo's skull sank to the bottom of Iwata-gawa River and a willow grew from the eye socket – it is this that causes your head to become painful whenever the wind blows and moves the skull."

However, Rengebo's skull sank to the bottom of Iwata-gawa River and a willow grew from the eye socket - it is this that causes your head to become painful whenever the wind blows and moves the skull.'

However, Rengebo's skull sank to the bottom of the Iwata-gawa River and a willow grew from the eye socket - it is this that causes your head to become painful whenever the wind blows and moves the skull.'
sen.cmt: "Iwata-gawa River"→"the Iwata-gawa River"に変更しました。

sen.j: 上皇が岩田川（現在の富田川）を調べさせるとお告げの通りであったので、三十三間堂の千手観音の中に髑髏を納め、柳の木を梁に使ったところ、上皇の頭痛は治ったという。
sen.e: It is said that when the retired emperor travelled to Iwata-gawa River (now Tonda-gawa River), it was just as he was told and his headaches were finally cured after he encapsulated the skull inside Sanjusangen-do Temple's statue of Senju-Kannon and used the wood of the willow tree to construct the beams.

It is said that when the retired emperor travelled to Iwata-gawa River (now Tonda-gawa River), it was just as he was told and his headaches were finally cured after he encapsulated the skull inside Sanjusangen-do Temple's statue of Senju-Kannon and used the wood of the willow tree to construct the beams.

It is said that when the retired emperor made the Iwata-gawa River (now the Tonda-gawa River) be investigated, it was just as he was told and his headaches were finally cured after he encapsulated the skull inside Sanjusangen-do Temple's statue of Senju-Kannon and used the wood of the willow tree to construct the beams.
sen.cmt: 「調べさせる」の訳を補足"Iwata-gawa River"→"the Iwata-gawa River"に変更しました。"Tonda-gawa River"→"the Tonda-gawa River"に変更しました。

sen.j: 「蓮華王院」という名前は前世の蓮華坊の名から取ったものであるという。
sen.e: It is also said that the 'Rengeo-in' main hall was named after the monk Rengebo from whom the emperor was reincarnated.
It is also said that the 'Rengeo-in' main hall was named after the monk Rengebo from whom the emperor was reincarnated.
It is also said that the 'Rengeo-in' main hall was named after the monk Rengebo from whom the emperor was reincarnated.

sen.j: この伝承により「頭痛封じの寺」として崇敬を受けるようになり、「頭痛山平癒寺」と俗称された。
sen.e: This legend led to the temple being revered as 'Zutsu-fuji no Tera' (or 'The Headache Preventing Temple') and its popular name 'Zutsu-zan Heiyu-ji' (Recovery Temple of Headache Mountain)
This legend led to the temple being revered as 'Zutsu-fuji no Tera' (or 'The Headache Preventing Temple') and its popular name 'Zutsu-zan Heiyu-ji' (Recovery Temple of Headache Mountain).
This legend led to the temple being revered as 'Zutsu-fuji no Tera' (or 'The Headache Preventing Temple') and its popular name 'Zutsu-zan Heiyu-ji' (Recovery Temple of Headache Mountain).

tit.e: The Origin and Structure of the Name 'Sanjusangen'
The Origin and Structure of the Name 'Sanjusangen'

sen.j: 三十三間堂の名称は、本堂が間面記法で「三十三間四面」となることに由来する。
sen.e: The name Sanjusangen-do Temple derives from the building's layout of '33 ken, 4 men'.
The name Sanjusangen-do Temple derives from the building's layout of '33 ken, 4 men.'
The name Sanjusangen-do Temple derives from the building's layout of '33 ken, 4 men.'

sen.j: これは桁行三十三間の周囲四面に一間の庇を巡らせたという意味である。
sen.e: This means that the structure consists of 33 ken (lengthwise bays), surrounded by aisles on all 4 sides.
This means that the structure consists of 33 ken (lengthwise bays), surrounded by eaves on all 4 sides.
This means that the structure consists of 33 ken (lengthwise bays), surrounded by eaves on all 4 sides.

sen.j: つまり柱間が33あるのは本堂の内陣（母屋）で、建物外部から見る柱間は35ある。
sen.e: Although is actually the main inner core (moya) of the temple that is 33 ken long and, from the outside, the building itself is 35 ken.
Although is actually the main inner core (moya) of the temple that is 33 ken long and, from the outside, the building itself is 35 ken.
Although is in fact the main inner core (moya) of the temple that is 33 ken long and, from the outside, the building itself is 35 ken.

sen.j: ここで言う「間」（けん）は長さの単位ではなく、社寺建築の柱間の数を表す建築用語である。
sen.e: The unit 'ken' is not a measurement length but an architectural term that represents the number of bays (space between two pillars) within a temple or shrine.
The unit 'ken' is not a measurement length but an architectural term that represents the number of bays (space between two pillars) within a temple or shrine.
The unit 'ken' is not a measurement length but an architectural term that represents the number of bays (space between two pillars) within a temple or shrine.

sen.j: 三十三間堂の柱間は一定ではなくその柱間も今日柱間として使われる京間・中京間・田舎間のどれにも該当しない。
sen.e: The space between two pillars in Sanjusangen-do Temple is not a fixed distance, nor does it correspond to any of the currently used Kyoma, Chukyoma or Inakama measurements.
The space between two pillars in Sanjusangen-do Temple is not a fixed distance, nor does it correspond to any of the currently used Kyoma, Chukyoma or Inakama measurements.
The space between two pillars in Sanjusangen-do Temple is not a fixed distance, nor does it correspond to any of the currently used Kyoma, Chukyoma or Inakama measurements.

sen.j: 「三十三間堂の1間（柱間）は今日の2間（12尺）に相当する」として堂の全長は33×2×1.818で約120m、と説明されることがあるが、これは柱間長についても、柱間数についても誤りである（ただし実際の外縁小口間の長さ約121mとほとんど一致する）。
sen.e: One explanation states that 1 of Sanjusangen-do Temple's ken (space between two pillars) is the equivalent of 2 of today's ken (12 shaku) to make the entire length of the hall approximately 120m (33x2x1.818) but this incorrect both in terms of the length of the space between pillars and the number of pillars (however, it essentially matches the actual external length of approximately 121m).

One explanation states that 1 of Sanjusangen-do Temple's ken (space between two pillars) is the equivalent of 2 of today's ken (12 shaku) to make the entire length of the hall approximately 120m (33x2x1.818) but this incorrect both in terms of the length of the space between pillars and the number of pillars (however, it essentially matches the actual external length of approximately 121m).

One explanation states that 1 of Sanjusangen-do Temple's ken (space between two pillars) is the equivalent of 2 of today's ken (12 shaku) to make the entire length of the hall approximately 120 meters (33 x 2 x 1.818) but this is incorrect both in terms of the length of the space between pillars and the number of pillars (however, it essentially matches the actual external length of approximately 121 meters).

sen.j: 湛慶晩年の建長6年（1254年）の作
sen.e: One of Tankei's later works created in 1254.
One of Tankei's later works created in 1254.
One of Tankei's later works created in 1254.

sen.j: 木造風神・雷神像 - 鎌倉復興期の作。
sen.e: Wooden statues of Fujin (wind god) and Raijin (thunder god) - Created during the temple revival stage of the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 堂内左右端に安置。
sen.e: Enshrined on the right and left sides of the inside of the hall.
Enshrined on the right and left sides of the inside of the hall.

sen.j: 風袋と太鼓をそれぞれ持った風神・雷神像の姿をユーモラスに表したこれらの像は、俵屋宗達の『風神雷神図屏風』のモデルになったともいわれる。
sen.e: It is also said that these humorous statues of Fujin with his bag of wind and Raijin with his drums were the inspiration for Sotatsu TAWARAYA's 'Fujin Raijin zu byobu' (folding screen depicting images of Fujin and Raijin).

It is also said that these humorous statues of Fujin with his bag of wind and Raijin with his drums were the inspiration for Sotatsu TAWARAYA's "Fujin Raijin zu byobu" (folding screen depicting images of Fujin and Raijin).

It is also said that these humorous statues of Fujin with his bag of wind and Raijin with his drums were the inspiration for Sotatsu TAWARAYA's "Fujin Raijin zu byobu" (folding screen depicting images of Fujin and Raijin).

sen.j: 木造二十八部衆立像 - 鎌倉復興期の作。
sen.e: Wooden standing statues of the Twenty-eight Attendants of Senju-Kannon) - Created during the temple revival stage of the Kamakura period.
sen.cmt: ・Wooden standing statues of the Twenty-eight Attendants of Senju-Kannon): http://www.onmarkproductions.com/html/28-bushu-kannon.shtml
sen.e: Wooden standing statues of the Twenty-eight Attendants of Senju-Kannon - Created during the temple revival stage of the Kamakura period.
Wooden standing statues of the Twenty-eight Attendants of Senju-Kannon - Created during the temple revival stage of the Kamakura period.

sen.j: 千体千手観音像の手前に横一列に立つ（28躯のうち四天王像4躯は本尊の周囲に立つ）。
sen.e: These stand in single file in front of the statue of Senju-Kannon (of the 28, the 4 statues of each of the Four Heavenly Kings surround the main deity.
These stand side by side in front of the one thousand statues of Senju-Kannon (of the 28, the 4 statues of each of the Four Heavenly Kings surround the main deity).
sen.cmt: 横一列→side by side千体→the one thousand statues ※本尊の背後のものを入れると1001体あるが、原文で千体とあるのでone thousand とした。文末に)を補足。
sen.e: These stand side by side in front of the one thousand statues of Senju-Kannon (of the 28, the 4 statues of each of the Four Heavenly Kings surround the main deity).

sen.j: 二十八部衆は千手観音の眷属で、仁王、四天王のようななじみの深い尊格のほか、婆藪仙人（ばすせんにん）、摩和羅女など、他ではあまり見かけない像も含む。
sen.e: The Twenty-eight Attendants are the followers of Senju-Kannon and include familiar deities such as Nio (two Deva Kings) and the Four Heavenly Kings as well as those not so well-known figures, which include Basusennin and Mawara-nyo.

The Twenty-eight Attendants are the followers of Senju-Kannon and include familiar deities such as Nio (two Deva Kings) and the Four Heavenly Kings as well as those not so well-known figures, which include Basusennin and Mawara-nyo.

The Twenty-eight Attendants are the followers of Senju-Kannon and include familiar deities such as Nio (two Deva Kings) and the Four Heavenly Kings as well as those not so well-known figures, which include Basusennin and Mawara-nyo.

sen.j: 痩せ衰えた老人の姿をリアルに表した婆藪仙人像は鎌倉彫刻の代表作として知られている。
sen.e: The realistic representation of an emaciated old Basusennin is known to be highly representative of Kamakura period sculpture.
The realistic representation of an emaciated old Basusennin is known to be highly representative of Kamakura period sculpture.
The realistic representation of an emaciated old Basusennin is known to be highly representative of Kamakura period sculpture.

tit.cmt: ・Important Cultural Properties: 英辞郎 on the WEB

sen.j: 南大門
sen.e: Nandai-mon gate
Nandai-mon gate
Nandai-mon gate

sen.j: 太閤塀
sen.e: Taikohei
Taikohei
Taikohei

sen.j: 木造千手観音立像（1,001躯）
sen.e: 1,001 wooden standing statues of Senju-Kannon
1,001 wooden standing statues of Senju-Kannon
1,001 wooden standing statues of Senju-Kannon

sen.j: 本尊の左右の階段状の仏壇に各10段50列、本尊の背後に1躯、計1,001躯が並ぶ。
sen.e: Statues stand on tiered altars 10 deep in two 50 row sections to the right and left of the principal deity with one more standing behind to make a total of 1,001.
Statues stand on tiered altars 10 deep in two 50 row sections to the right and left of the principal deity with one more standing behind to make a total of 1,001.
Statues stand on tiered altars 10 deep in two 50 row sections to the right and left of the principal deity with one more standing behind to make a total of 1,001.

sen.j: 像高は166 － 167cm前後。
sen.e: These measure approximately 166-157cm in height.
These measure approximately 166-167cm in height.
These measure approximately 166 - 167 centimeters in height.

sen.j: 大部分は鎌倉復興期の作だが、建長元年（1249）の火災の際、救い出された平安期の像も124躯含まれる（他に室町時代に追加された像が1躯だけある）。
sen.e: The majority were crafted during the temple revival stage of the Kamakura period but the collection also includes 124 Heian period statues that escaped the fire of 1249 (in addition to one statue added during the Muromachi period).

The majority were crafted during the temple revival stage of the Kamakura period but the collection also includes 124 Heian period statues that escaped the fire of 1249 (in addition to one statue added during the Muromachi period).

The majority were crafted during the temple revival stage of the Kamakura period but the collection also includes 124 Heian period statues that escaped the fire of 1249 (in addition to one statue added during the Muromachi period).

sen.j: 平安時代の像は作者不明だが、鎌倉復興像は二百数十躯に作者銘があり、湛慶をはじめ慶派、院派、円派など、当時の主要な仏師たちが総出で造像にあたったことがわかる。
sen.e: It is not known who created the Heian period statues, but over 200 of the Kamakura revival era statues bear the inscriptions of their makers, which include Tankei as well as sculptors of renowned schools of Buddhist statuary such as the Keiha school, Impa school and Empa school, and make it clear that the most prominent Buddhist statue artisans of the era participated in their creation.

It is not known who created the Heian period statues, but over 200 of the Kamakura revival era statues bear the inscriptions of their makers, which include Tankei as well as sculptors of renowned schools of Buddhist statuary such as the Keiha school, Impa school and Empa school, and make it clear that the most prominent Buddhist statue artisans of the era participated in their creation.

It is not known who created the Heian period statues, but over 200 of the Kamakura revival era statues bear the inscriptions of their makers, which include Tankei as well as sculptors of renowned schools of Buddhist statuary such as the Keiha school, Impa school and Empa school, and make it clear that the most prominent Buddhist statue artisans of the era participated in their creation.

sen.j: 1,001躯のうちの5躯は東京・京都・奈良の国立博物館に寄託されている。
sen.e: Of the 1,001 statues, 5 have been deposited with the National museums of Tokyo, Kyoto and Nara.
Of the 1,001 statues, 5 have been deposited with the National museums of Tokyo, Kyoto and Nara.
Of the 1,001 statues, 5 have been deposited with the National museums of Tokyo, Kyoto and Nara.

sen.j: 兵庫県・朝光寺本尊である2躯の千手観音菩薩立像のうち1躯は三十三間堂の観音像と様式が一致し、当堂から移されたものと推定されている。
sen.e: One of the two standing statues of Senju-Kannon that serve as the principle objects of veneration at Hyogo Prefecture's Choko-ji Temple is in the style of those of Sanjusangen-do Temple and it is assumed to have been relocated from the hall.

One of the two standing statues of Senju-Kannon that serve as the principle objects of veneration at Hyogo Prefecture's Choko-ji Temple is in the style of those of Sanjusangen-do Temple and it is assumed to have been relocated from the hall.
sen.cmt: Choko-jiの前のスペースを調整。
sen.e: One of the two standing statues of Senju-Kannon that serve as the principle objects of veneration at Hyogo Prefecture's Choko-ji Temple is in the style of those of Sanjusangen-do Temple and it is assumed to have been relocated from the hall.
